body: Agree that we should standardize here. This also affects raw bytestrings: `rb'x'` and `br'x'` are both valid.

Just sharing that I  also would like this.

I vote for alphabetical just for a simple standard. `sort()` would just do it then I feel.

```python
fr"foo"
br"foo"
```

Seconded. I weakly prefer `rb"x"` and `fr"x"` visually since they are recognizable pairs to me (rb is a Ruby file extension and fr is a code for French which I can speak some of). But going with the general standard and what tools prefer is definitely better.

edit: or some basic rule like Cooper's one above this comment works too

@cooperlees you mean `br`? :D

```python
>>> bf"foo"
  File "<stdin>", line 1
    bf"foo"
      ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
>>> 
```

edit and off-topic: I just realized I can edit anyone's comment now, I guess I could've done that instead lol

> @cooperlees you mean `br`? :D
> 
> ```python
> >>> bf"foo"
>   File "<stdin>", line 1
>     bf"foo"
>       ^
> SyntaxError: invalid syntax
> >>> 
> ```

Sure ...

While having a simple rule is elegant, I think matching spoken word is important like James pointed out. Just to provide one more perspective, I'd prefer:

- `rf` - raw f-string
- `rb` - raw byte string

The simple rule in this case would be "have `r` first", if simplicity is important.

I don't think the alphabetical order convention is a good one, otherwise you might end up with inconsistent placing e.g. `br`, `fr` and `rx` (under the hypothetical scenario where `x` and `rx` are a valid prefixes). I'd prefer either "r-first"---as in "raw f-string/byte string"---or "r-last"---as in the "f" or "b" are the most important parts of the prefix or possibly chain-rule i.e. the "raw" processing is applied before the "format" processing; I don't know how the parser actually handles it.

To me, "r-first"---as in "raw f-string/byte string"---is the clearest justification.

Sorting will also have problems with [the capital-R prefix](https://black.readthedocs.io/en/stable/the_black_code_style/current_style.html#r-strings-and-r-strings), `Rf""`, `Rb""`, `br""`, `fr""`.  I'd prefer "r-last" (`fR""`, `bR""`) but would be happy with any simple and consistent rule.

@Zac-HD I didn't know about the R-strings. Thanks for that :+1:. Seems odd to have the more common syntax (i.e. lower case r) be for the special case of regular expressions, especially when `br""` doesn't make sense ... I think, but I digress.

I think I agree that `fR""` looks better than `Rf""`. In fact, I'm also moving towards the view that the "best" justification is "r-last" since it is less important than the "f" or "b", even if this isn't as "clear" as "r-first" as in "raw f-string".

To find some common ground first, I think it would be reasonable to propose that no matter which "r/R", the order stays the same. Meaning no mixing `rf` with `fR` and vice versa. And I think allowing other capital letters is a no-go as well. So it seems that the suggestions have converged to:

- `r` first, as in spoken word: `rb"str", rf"str", Rb"str", Rf"str"`
- `r` last, as the common attribute applicable to both `b` and `f`: `br"str", fr"str", bR"str", fR"str"`

Personally I still feel like matching spoken word is more important, and I'm not bothered by the capital "R" being first. That being said arguments can be made both ways. Would the maintainers like to decide, or would we vote, or have a PR race? ðŸ˜„
We just need to make the call, one way or the other. Maybe ask for more opinions on Discord and then take a majority vote among the maintainers.

I've voted on the poll on Discord, but to explain why I voted for things like `fr` I think it makes more sense for them to be in alphabetical order if they're going to be standardised, as other things' order also follow that pattern

After 8 hours the [poll](https://discord.com/channels/267624335836053506/846434317021741086/846865880742756382) is 8-5 for `rf`. Could the maintainers only vote here thumbs up for `r` first and down for `r` last?

issue.title: Normalise string prefix order

labels.name: F: strings
labels.description: Related to our handling of strings

issue.body:
Closes #2171: this PR makes _Black_ normalise string prefix order. Since no other maintainer but Jelle responded to the last poll, I went ahead and put <strike>"r" first since it was also the winner of the first poll. But that's easy to change if you'd like.</strike> (<strike>"r" last now, see issue and below</strike> ("r" first now again lol))

- [x] Tests and changed existing tests and source to comply
- [x] Changelog and style documentation
- [x] 100% money back guarantee

---
Also, don't worry: I wrote "normalize" to the source for consistency. And for freedom! ðŸ¦…

body:
I opened the PR to fix this. It seems that in Python 2 the order is not arbitrary and two combinations: `ur` and `br` are the only valid ones. They go against `r` first.

Since `ur` is invalid in Python 3, I'm inclined to introduce a special case for Python 2 and let the rule be. Another option would be to just use `r` last and call it a day. Thoughts?

---

<strike>Let's deprecate Python 2 parsing lol</strike>
Given that no-one had strong feelings about which way round it should be, maybe it's better to switch to r-last for consistency with Python 2.
Update: since we're dropping Python 2 now in #2740, I think I'll go with our original option of "r" first.
